Introduction to Gosu

Lesson
objectives

¢ Describe the ways that Guidewire
applications use Gosu

¢ Write Gosu using basic Gosu syntax

* Describe Studio features that aid in the writing
of Gosu

Using Gosu to configure the Application
Tier

Guidewire Gosu

Guidewire's programming language
* Similar to Java and compatible with Java

* Has elements of both procedural and object-oriented
programming languages

Executes fundamental application behavior
Manages complex business processes
Executes hierarchical Gosu Rules

Specifies dynamic user interface behavior

ss GOSU

Gosu in Guidewire applications (1 of 3)

i
¢ Apply specific programming logic for ¢ Extend entity functionality with
testing a condition and performing programming logic as entity

an action methods

¢ Examples: ¢ Examples:

¢ Event Fired Rules « ABCompany.maskTaxld()

* Pre-update Rules returns a value with a mask for the first 5

characters
« Validation Rules

Gosu in Guidewire applications (2 of 3) fa

¢ Programming logic that defines how ¢ Encapsulate data and code for a

to display a name for an entity specific purpose or function
instance * Examples:
+ Examples: + Utility helper classes for logging or string
* Drop-down lists of contacts functions
* DisplayName property of entity instance « Plugins for integrations with other
applications

@ ©

Gosu in Guidewire applications (3 of 3)

Run custom business processes
asynchronously, optionally with
multiple states that transition over time
Examples:

+ Renewal and cancelation workflows

Arrays G

<array/> on parent ¢ Entity enhancement ¢ Aset of values are of
entity to array entity or Guidewire API the same type ina
<foreignkey/> on single collection
array entity to parent + Example

entity ¢ Examples

+ ABContact AllAddresses .
Example property returns an * var a = new int[3]
+ ABContact defines Address array + var b = new int[]
FlagEntries array {1,2,3}

*varc: int[] =
{1,2,3}

Array methods that require logic

« Array methods include
* Getting information about the array
* Getting members of the array that match a given condition
*« Some methods require an argument
« Argument must be an expression of a condition, such as:
¢ Returns true if any row in the array matches the condition
« Returns the first row that matches the condition
* Returns all rows that match the condition

« Argument must be a Gosu block expression

Common array methods (1 of 2)

¢ hasMatch (condition)
* Determine if any element in an array matches a given condition
* Syntax: array. hasMatch (\ name -> conditionToMatch)
* countWhere (condition)

¢ Returns count of elements that match a given condition in an array
¢ Syntax: array.countWhere(\ name -> conditionToMatch)

Common array methods (2 of 2) fa

¢ firstWhere (condition)
¢ Retrieve the first element in an array that matches a given condition
* Syntax: array. firstWhere (\ name -> conditionToMatch)
¢ where (condition)

« Retrieves a target array that consists of all the members of a source array that match a given
condition

¢ Syntax: array.where(\ name -> conditionToMatch)

Blocks argument expression Gi
ORORO)

var notes = someNotes.where( \ note ->

@ note.ContactNoteType == typekey.ContactNoteType.TC_GENERAL)

¢ Ablock is an expression of logic passed to a method as an argument
« Some array methods require conditions using a block
¢ The block consists of four parts:

1. \, which identifies that the following is a block

2. Anelement name representing each element of the array
3. ->, which identifies the start of the condition
4

A condition, which relates to the element

About rational numbers Gi

Rounding large decimal numbers is often required when numbers scale to infinity
(i.e. 1/3 = 0.3333333333...), however, the rounding will produce data errors over
time as the numbers are used in other calculations (data loss)

gw.util.Rational has an infinite scale which allows you to preserve whatever
value is placed in it

gw.util.money and gw.util.science store numbers as Rationals. This means
using and testing data with those libraries becomes easier and more accurate

Arithmetic operators can be applied to rational numbers using the following syntax:
Rational.add(i)

Rational.subtract(i)

Rational.multiply(i)

Rational.divide(i)

Rational.class in Gosu =

© gw.uta,

11 Project

public gw.util.Rational invert() ( /* compiled code */ }

public gw.util.Rational abs() ( /* compile

public gy.util.Rational pow (int exponent)

Using rational numbers Gi

¢ Examples of declaring Rational literals:

//prints 31476765859979876 / 10000000000000000
var myRational= Rational.get (3.147676585997987798798)

print (myRational)

//prints 1/3

var rationalFraction = Rational.get(1,3)
print (rationalFraction)

//prints 3/12

var rationalString = Rational.get ("3/12")

print (rationalString)
